block.p: Bebe Moore Campbell's examination of the agitation felt by some black women when they are confronted with romances between black men and white women overlooks an important consideration: commonly underlying their anguish is a fear of losing control over increasingly independent black men (Hers: "Brothers and Sisters," Aug. 23).

African-American men who have been brutalized by white racists for courting white women must now face the additional burden of black women's jealousy and ostracism for exercising their rights in choosing a mate. Both groups, though on opposite sides, are telling black men to stay in their place.

Bebe Moore Campbell's examination of the agitation felt by some black women when they are confronted with romances between black men and white women overlooks an important consideration: commonly underlying their anguish is a fear of losing control over increasingly independent black men (Hers: "Brothers and Sisters," Aug. 23).

African-American men who have been brutalized by white racists for courting white women must now face the additional burden of black women's jealousy and ostracism for exercising their rights in choosing a mate. Both groups, though on opposite sides, are telling black men to stay in their place.
Black men struggling for liberation in America should not trade one form of oppression for another. ALVIN F. POUSSAINT, M.D. Associate Professor of Psychiatry, Harvard Medical School
